query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 E io, continüando al mio sermone, 8 dissi: «Ella sen va sù forse più tarda 9 che non farebbe, per altrui cagione.
query.result:
**English:**
7 And I, continuing my speech, 8 said: "She is perhaps going up later 9 than she would, because of another reason.
**Old English:**
7 And ic ða furðor ðinum wordum cwæð, 8 "Heo gæð nu uppon sumre sæle lætre 9 ðonne heo ær dyde, for ðære ðearfe ðe heo hæfð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Ma dimmi, se tu sai, dov’ è Piccarda; 11 dimmi s’io veggio da notar persona 12 tra questa gente che sì mi riguarda».
query.result:
**English:**
10 But tell me, if you know, where is Piccarda; 11 tell me if I see anyone worthy of note 12 among these people who are watching me so intently.
**Old English:**
10 Ac sege me, gif ðu wast, hwær is Piccarda; 11 sege me, gif ic mæg oncnawan ænigne 12 ðara manna ðe swa me bihaldað».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 «La mia sorella, che tra bella e buona 14 non so qual fosse più, trïunfa lieta 15 ne l’alto Olimpo già di sua corona».
query.result:
**English:**
13 "My sister, who between beautiful and good 14 I do not know which was more, triumphs joyful 15 in high Olympus already with her crown."
**Old English:**
13 "Min sweoster, ðe betwux fæger and god 14 nis me ðæs soð to secganne hwæðer wæs mare, 15 on ðam hean heofone nu hire blisse brucað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Sì disse prima; e poi: «Qui non si vieta 17 di nominar ciascun, da ch’è sì munta 18 nostra sembianza via per la dïeta.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Thus he spoke first; and then: "Here it is not forbidden 17 to name each one, since our appearance is so changed 18 by our journey through the diet."
**Old English:**
16 Swa cwæð he ærest; and ða eft: "Her nis nân ðearf 17 ðæt ænig mon his naman ne cunne, 18 forðæm ðe ure hiw bið forwandod ðurh ðone wæstm."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Questi», e mostrò col dito, «è Bonagiunta, 20 Bonagiunta da Lucca; e quella faccia 21 di là da lui più che l’altre trapunta
22 ebbe la Santa Chiesa in le sue braccia: 23 dal Torso fu, e purga per digiuno 24 l’anguille di Bolsena e la vernaccia».
query.result:
**English:**
19 "This one," and he pointed with his finger, "is Bonagiunta, 20 Bonagiunta da Lucca; and that face 21 over there, more adorned than the others,
22 the Holy Church held in her arms: 23 he was from Tours, and he purges by fasting 24 the eels of Bolsena and the vernaccia wine."
**Old English:**
19 "Þes," and he tæhte mid his fingre, "is Bonagiunta, 20 Bonagiunta of Lucca; and ðæt neb 21 ðær ofer him ma þonne ða oðre getrymmed,
22 hæfde ða Halgan Cirice on hire earmum: 23 of Tours he wæs, and he þurh fæsten clænsað 24 ða æles of Bolsena and ða vernaccia."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Molti altri mi nomò ad uno ad uno; 26 e del nomar parean tutti contenti, 27 sì ch’io però non vidi un atto bruno.
query.result:
**English:**
25 Many others he named to me, one by one; 26 and they all seemed content to be named, 27 so that I did not see a single frown.
**Old English:**
25 Manega oðre he me nemde, anne be anum; 26 and ðæs nemnan ða wæron ealle blide, 27 swa ðæt ic ðær ne geseah ænne brunne leomu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Vidi per fame a vòto usar li denti 29 Ubaldin da la Pila e Bonifazio 30 che pasturò col rocco molte genti.
query.result:
**English:**
28 I saw Ubaldin della Pila and Bonifazio 29 gnawing at each other in their hunger, 30 he who shepherded many people with his crook.
**Old English:**
28 Ic geseah ðurh hungor Ubaldin ðone 29 and Bonifacium ðone bisceop 30 se ðe mid gyrde manega gehæfde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Vidi messer Marchese, ch’ebbe spazio 32 già di bere a Forlì con men secchezza, 33 e sì fu tal, che non si sentì sazio.
query.result:
**English:**
31 I saw Messer Marchese, who had the opportunity 32 to drink in Forlì with less dryness, 33 and he was such that he did not feel satisfied.
**Old English:**
31 Ic geseah ðone æðelan Marchese, se hæfde ðone sped 32 ðæt he moste drincan æt Forlì mid læsse ðurste, 33 and he wæs swylc ðæt he ne mæg næfre beon gefylled.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Ma come fa chi guarda e poi s’apprezza 35 più d’un che d’altro, fei a quel da Lucca, 36 che più parea di me aver contezza.
query.result:
**English:**
34 But as one does who looks and then draws near 35 more to one than to another, I did to that one from Lucca, 36 who seemed to have more knowledge of me.
**Old English:**
34 Ac swa swa ðeð ðe lociað and ðonne genealæcað 35 ma ðonne to ðam oðrum ðonne to ðam ðriddan, dyde ic to ðam of Luca, 36 ðe me ðuhte ðæt he me bet cuðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 El mormorava; e non so che «Gentucca» 38 sentiv’ io là, ov’ el sentia la piaga 39 de la giustizia che sì li pilucca.
query.result:
**English:**
37 He murmured; and I know not what "Gentucca" 38 I heard there, where he felt the wound 39 of justice that so plucks at them.
**Old English:**
37 He murnede; and ic nat hwet "Gentucca" 38 ic ðær gehyrde, ðær he ða wunde 39 ðære rihtwisnesse ðe swa ða ruggeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 «O anima», diss’ io, «che par sì vaga 41 di parlar meco, fa sì ch’io t’intenda, 42 e te e me col tuo parlare appaga».
query.result:
**English:**
40 "O soul," I said, "who seem so eager 41 to speak with me, do so that I may understand you, 42 and satisfy both you and me with your speech."
**Old English:**
40 "Eala ðu sawul," cwæð ic, "ðe ðinceð swa gewis 41 ðæt ðu wille sprecan wið me, wyrc swa ðæt ic ðe gehyre, 42 and geðwær ðe and me mid ðinum wordum."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 «Femmina è nata, e non porta ancor benda», 44 cominciò el, «che ti farà piacere 45 la mia città, come ch’om la riprenda.
query.result:
**English:**
43 "A woman is born, and she does not yet wear a veil," 44 he began, "who will make my city pleasing to you, 45 however much people may criticize it.
**Old English:**
43 "Wifmon is geboren, and ne gæð giet ða gyt," 44 ongan he, "ðe ðe ðine wille bringð, 45 ðine burge ðe ðeah mon mænige tæle."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Tu te n’andrai con questo antivedere: 47 se nel mio mormorar prendesti errore, 48 dichiareranti ancor le cose vere.
query.result:
**English:**
46 You will depart with this foreknowledge: 47 if you misunderstood my murmuring, 48 true things will still declare it to you.
**Old English:**
46 ðu ðe scealt faran mid ðysum foresceawunge: 47 gif ðu on minum murcunge miswende, 48 ðe secgað ða soðan ðing.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Ma dì s’i’ veggio qui colui che fore 50 trasse le nove rime, cominciando 51 ‘Donne ch’avete intelletto d’amore’».
query.result:
**English:**
49 But tell me if I see here the one who first 50 composed the new rhymes, beginning 51 “Ladies who have intelligence of love.”
**Old English:**
49 Ac secge me ðu ðeah ðæt ic ðær geseah ðone 50 ðe ærest song on stefne staðolade, 51 “Wif, ðe hafað ðæs modes cræft.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 E io a lui: «I’ mi son un che, quando 53 Amor mi spira, noto, e a quel modo 54 ch’e’ ditta dentro vo significando».
query.result:
**English:**
52 And I to him: "I am one who, when 53 Love breathes into me, takes note, and in that manner 54 which is dictated to me within, I go on to signify."
**Old English:**
52 And ic to him: "Ic eom an ðe, ðonne 53 Lufu me blæseð, gecnawe, and on ðam wisan 54 ðe me is innan gecweden ic fare getacniende."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 «O frate, issa vegg’ io», diss’ elli, «il nodo 56 che ’l Notaro e Guittone e me ritenne 57 di qua dal dolce stil novo ch’i’ odo!
58 Io veggio ben come le vostre penne 59 di retro al dittator sen vanno strette, 60 che de le nostre certo non avvenne;
61 e qual più a gradire oltre si mette, 62 non vede più da l’uno a l’altro stilo»; 63 e, quasi contentato, si tacette.
query.result:
**English:**
55 "O brother, now I see," he said, "the knot 56 that Notary and Guittone and me 57 held back from the sweet new style that I hear!
58 I see well how your pens 59 follow closely behind the dictator, 60 which certainly did not happen with ours;
61 and whoever sets out to please more 62 no longer sees the difference from one style to another"; 63 and, almost satisfied, he fell silent.
**Old English:**
55 "Eala broðor, nu ic geseo," cwæð he, "ðone cnotan 56 ðe ðe Notarius and Guittone and mec 57 heoldon her on ðisum sidan ðæs swetan stiles ðe ic gehyrde!
58 Ic geseo wel hu ðine pena 59 æfter ðam writere farað fæste, 60 ðæt ne geweard na mid urum;
61 and se ðe wille ðe mare lician, 62 he ne gesihð na ðone mislicum stilan"; 63 and, swilce he wære geblissad, ða geswog he.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Come li augei che vernan lungo ’l Nilo, 65 alcuna volta in aere fanno schiera, 66 poi volan più a fretta e vanno in filo,
67 così tutta la gente che lì era, 68 volgendo ’l viso, raffrettò suo passo, 69 e per magrezza e per voler leggera.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Like the birds that winter along the Nile, 65 sometimes in the air they form a flock, 66 then fly faster and go in a line,
67 so all the people who were there, 68 turning their faces, hastened their pace, 69 and because of their thinness and desire to be light.
**Old English:**
64 Swa ða fugelas ðe on wintra fleogað be Nilum, 65 hwilum hi on lyfte lætað heora feðru, 66 ðonne hi fliogað swiðost and farað on here,
67 eall swa ða leoda ðe ðær wæron, 68 wendon heora neb and hrade ða ferdon, 69 for heora mægrenesse and for ðæs willan ðe hi woldon beon leoht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 E come l’uom che di trottare è lasso, 71 lascia andar li compagni, e sì passeggia 72 fin che si sfoghi l’affollar del casso,
73 sì lasciò trapassar la santa greggia 74 Forese, e dietro meco sen veniva, 75 dicendo: «Quando fia ch’io ti riveggia?».
query.result:
**English:**
70 And like the man who is weary from running, 71 lets his companions go on, and walks slowly 72 until he recovers from his breathlessness,
73 so Forese let the holy flock pass by, 74 and came walking behind me, 75 saying: "When will I see you again?"
**Old English:**
70 And swa swa se ðegn ðe bið werig of wege, 71 læteð his geferan faran forð, and he gæð 72 oððæt he ðone cearo of his heortan hæfð,
73 swa læt ða halgan heorda Forese faran, 74 and æfter me com sprecende ðus: 75 "Hwænne mæg ic ðe eft geseon?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 «Or va», diss’ el; «che quei che più n’ha colpa, 83 vegg’ ïo a coda d’una bestia tratto 84 inver’ la valle ove mai non si scolpa.
query.result:
**English:**
82 "Now go," he said, "for the one who is most to blame for this, 83 I see him dragged by the tail of a beast 84 toward the valley where no one is ever absolved."
**Old English:**
82 "Nu ga," cwæð he, "for ðam ðe mæst ðæs gyltes hæfð, 83 ic hine geseo ðurh deofles cræft 84 to ðære helle ðær næfre mon ne mæg hine ahlæsan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 La bestia ad ogne passo va più ratto, 86 crescendo sempre, fin ch’ella il percuote, 87 e lascia il corpo vilmente disfatto.
query.result:

85 The beast at every step goes faster, 86 ever increasing, until it strikes him, 87 and leaves his body vilely mangled.
**Old English:**
85 Se deor ðe swiftra on ðam siðe weorðað, 86 oððæt he ðone monnan mid mocy forwurde, 87 ond ðone lichoman leaðe forlæteð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Non hanno molto a volger quelle ruote», 89 e drizzò li occhi al ciel, «che ti fia chiaro 90 ciò che ’l mio dir più dichiarar non puote.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Those wheels do not have much to turn, 89 and he raised his eyes to the sky, "it will be clear to you 90 what my words cannot explain any more."
**Old English:**
88 Ne þa hweol ða hwile mycel fæc ne beoð, 89 and he his eagan to heofonum arærde, "ðe bið swipe cuð 90 þæt min word ne mæg æfre mare gesecgan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Tu ti rimani omai; ché ’l tempo è caro 92 in questo regno, sì ch’io perdo troppo 93 venendo teco sì a paro a paro».
query.result:
**English:**
91 You remain here now; for time is precious 92 in this realm, so that I lose too much 93 coming with you side by side like this.”
**Old English:**
91 ðu ðe nu her wuna; for ðam ðe timan sind deore 92 on ðissum rice, swa ðæt ic to fela tyne 93 cumande mid ðe swa efenlice.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Qual esce alcuna volta di gualoppo 95 lo cavalier di schiera che cavalchi, 96 e va per farsi onor del primo intoppo,
97 tal si partì da noi con maggior valchi; 98 e io rimasi in via con esso i due 99 che fuor del mondo sì gran marescalchi.
query.result:
**English:**
94 As sometimes a horseman spurs his steed 95 out of the ranks to win the first encounter, 96 and goes to win honor from the initial clash,
97 so he departed from us with greater strides; 98 and I remained on the road with those two 99 who were such great marshals of the world.
**Old English:**
94 Swa sum wealdes mon his wæpnedcynnes 95 on gefeohte ford, ðonne he frumsceaft 96 wære wiges heard, and on werode 97 mægen strengest, and on mearce snelest,
98 swa ða from ðam folce forð gewat 99 se hearda hæleð under helm dreorig, 100 and ic mid ðam twæm ða gen wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 E quando innanzi a noi intrato fue, 101 che li occhi miei si fero a lui seguaci, 102 come la mente a le parole sue,
103 parvermi i rami gravidi e vivaci 104 d’un altro pomo, e non molto lontani 105 per esser pur allora vòlto in laci.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And when he had entered before us, 101 so that my eyes became his followers, 102 as my mind was of his words,
103 the branches seemed to me heavy and lively 104 with another fruit, and not very far away, 105 for it had just then turned to snares.
**Old English:**
100 And ða ða he ær us inngangen wæs, 101 ðæt mine eagan him folgedon, 102 swa min mod his wordum dyde,
103 ða ðuhte me ða telgan hefige and geðigene 104 oðres wæstmes, and næs ða wyrm feor 105 ðe ða wæs ðær gewended to lace.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Vidi gente sott’ esso alzar le mani 107 e gridar non so che verso le fronde, 108 quasi bramosi fantolini e vani
109 che pregano, e ’l pregato non risponde, 110 ma, per fare esser ben la voglia acuta, 111 tien alto lor disio e nol nasconde.
query.result:
**English:**
106 I saw people beneath it raising their hands 107 and crying out I know not what toward the leaves, 108 like greedy and vain little children
109 who beg, and the one begged does not respond, 110 but, to make the desire sharp, 111 he keeps their desire high and does not hide it.
**Old English:**
106 Ic geseah folc ðær under up aræran 107 heora handa and hlud cleopian, 108 swylce gitsende and idel cild,
109 ðe biddað and se gebedene ne gehyreð, 110 ac for ðære wilnunge ðe heora hyge trymð, 111 he heora wilnunge heah healdeð and ne hydeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Poi si partì sì come ricreduta; 113 e noi venimmo al grande arbore adesso, 114 che tanti prieghi e lagrime rifiuta.
query.result:
**English:**
112 Then she departed as if reassured; 113 and we came to the great tree now, 114 which rejects so many prayers and tears.
**Old English:**
112 Þa heo gewende swa heo wære getrymmed; 113 and we comon ða to ðam miclan treowe, 114 ðe swa fela bene and teare forscunað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 «Trapassate oltre sanza farvi presso: 116 legno è più sù che fu morso da Eva, 117 e questa pianta si levò da esso».
query.result:
**English:**
115 "Pass on without stopping: 116 there is a tree higher up that was bitten by Eve, 117 and this plant grew from it."
**Old English:**
115 "Gað furðor ðonne, ne ðe her wuna: 116 heahðu is heonon ðær ðe ðæt wif gewat, 117 and ðeos ðistel ðanon up spran."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Sì tra le frasche non so chi diceva; 119 per che Virgilio e Stazio e io, ristretti, 120 oltre andavam dal lato che si leva.
query.result:
**English:**
118 Thus among the leaves I know not who was speaking; 119 wherefore Virgil and Statius and I, huddled together, 120 went onward along the side that rises.
**Old English:**
118 Swa betwux ðam leafum ic nat hwa cwæð; 119 forðæm ða Fergilius and Statius and ic, tosomne geðrycced, 120 forð eodon be ðam sidan ðe him ðuhte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Sì accostati a l’un d’i due vivagni 128 passammo, udendo colpe de la gola 129 seguite già da miseri guadagni.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Thus we approached one of the two living flames, 128 hearing the sins of gluttony 129 followed now by wretched gains.
**Old English:**
127 Þus we genealæhton ðæm anum ðæra twega lifigendra fyrena, 128 gehyrende synna ðæra gifera 129 ða ðe ða earmlice gemanan folgiað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Poi, rallargati per la strada sola, 131 ben mille passi e più ci portar oltre, 132 contemplando ciascun sanza parola.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Then, spreading out along the lonely road, 131 a good thousand paces and more carried us onward, 132 each of us contemplating in silence.
**Old English:**
130 Þa we ða forð gewendon on ðone wudu wæstmestan, 131 þusend mila and ma þær ofer mearc stopon, 132 and ða geþohtes wæron wæge.
**Notes:**
* Line 130: "wæstmestan" is the superlative form of "west," meaning "westernmost." * Line 131: "mila" is the plural form of "mil," meaning "mile." * Line 132: "wæge" is the plural form of "weg," meaning "way" or "path."
Please let me know if you have any other questions.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 «Che andate pensando sì voi sol tre?». 134 sùbita voce disse; ond’ io mi scossi 135 come fan bestie spaventate e poltre.
query.result:
**English:**
133 "What are you three thinking about so intently?". 134 A sudden voice said; whereupon I started 135 like frightened and sluggish beasts.
**Old English:**
133 "Hwæt þenceað ge þrēo swa anrædlice?". 134 Hwilce stefne hē ðā spræc; þā ic me onscunode 135 swa ðā gedrecedan and ðā slæpan deor.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Drizzai la testa per veder chi fossi; 137 e già mai non si videro in fornace 138 vetri o metalli sì lucenti e rossi,
139 com’ io vidi un che dicea: «S’a voi piace 140 montare in sù, qui si convien dar volta; 141 quinci si va chi vuole andar per pace».
query.result:
**English:**
136 I raised my head to see who he was; 137 and never were glass or metals seen in a furnace 138 so bright and red,
139 as I saw one who said: "If it pleases you 140 to climb up, here you must turn; 141 this way goes he who wants to go in peace."
**Old English:**
136 Ic ða min heafod up ahof 137 and næfre ær on fyres ofne 138 glæs ne gold gyldenre leohtor
139 geseah ðonne ðone ðe ðus cwæð: 140 "Gif ðe licað ðæt ðu lædan wille 141 ðurh ðas dimman dalas, ðonne scealt ðu ðisne weg faran."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 L’aspetto suo m’avea la vista tolta; 143 per ch’io mi volsi dietro a’ miei dottori, 144 com’ om che va secondo ch’elli ascolta.
query.result:
**English:**
142 Her appearance had taken away my sight; 143 so I turned back to my guides, 144 like one who walks as he hears.
**Old English:**
142 Hire ansyn me hæfde ða gesyhðe benumen; 143 forðæm ic me wende eft to minum lareowum, 144 swa swa ðone mon ðe gæð swa swa he gehýreð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 E senti’ dir: «Beati cui alluma 152 tanto di grazia, che l’amor del gusto 153 nel petto lor troppo disir non fuma,
154 esurïendo sempre quanto è giusto!».
query.result:
**English:**
151 And heard say: "Blessed are those to whom so much 152 grace is kindled, that the love of taste 153 does not smoke too much desire in their breast,
154 hungering always for as much as is right!".
**Old English:**
151 And ic gehyrde secgan: "Eadig synt ða ðe swa mycel 152 gife onlihteð, ðæt ðæs swæces lufu 153 on heora breostum to ðæs miclan gitsunge ne rycð,
154 symble ðæs gerysnendlic ðæs ðe riht is!".
